title: Get started with Native SACM
content:
Native SACM is a single solution for the entire Service Asset & Configuration Management (SACM) process with instant access to the data and embedded graphical widgets for CI topology representation.

Instead of a loosely coupled and single-directional data replication, Native SACM is a natively connected solution that enables bi-directional data federation between Service Management and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB.

Comparison

Native SACM is optional. You may have no integration, continue to use the integration with UCMDB based on OPB, use Native SACM, or use a custom integration. 

Service Management without UCMDB 

Service Management with UCMDB based on OPB 

Service Management with Native SACM 

It's difficult to manually keep models up to date. 

Scheduled data synchronization to Service Management. 

Real-time data federation for up-to-date services and inventory. 

Unidirectional data flow from UCMDB to Service Management. 

Bi-directional data flow. 

Limited CI types are supported out of the box. Other CI types can be added with customization. 

Limited CI types are federated. 

Service model and CI topology can be maintained in Service Management and UCMDB. 

One service model and CI topology. 

End-to-end lifecycle from asset to CI. 

Auditing, including federated attributes. 

Enriched CI information. 

Configurable CI topology and impact rules. 

Codeless extension of CI attributes and codeless configurability of business rules for federated data. 

Use cases

This section lists common use cases covered by Native SACM. These are examples only to give an overview and are not meant to be complete. 

Bi-directional data exchange 

Services or CIs created in Service Management are now directly created in UCMDB without any delay. Any CIs created in UCMDB, for example, via discovery, are available in Service Management in real-time. 

Any changes to the data on either side are reflected immediately. 

After Native SACM is enabled, by default, all federated CIs are synchronized from UCMDB to Service Management. However, if you don’t want to view specific UCMDB CIs in Service Management, you can restrict the CI synchronization from UCMDB to Service Management by configuring the corresponding default value for sd_type for unwanted CIs in UCMDB. For details, see CI synchronization control through Subtype and sd_type mapping. 

Service/CI topology 

With Native SACM, the Service/CI topology is driven by UCMDB's powerful modeling capabilities. All Service/CI relations are kept in one place and are consistently used in Service Management. With Native SACM, the topologies can be modified based on the TQLs defined in UCMDB. Customers are now able to view the topology without restrictions in Service Management.

Impact assessment 

Another key use case is to have a powerful impact assessment feature. With Native SACM, impact assessment is driven by UCMDB's impact rules. Customers are now able to configure the rules based on their requirements. 

Codeless extension of CI attributes and codeless configurability of business rules for federated data 

With Native SACM, it’s super easy to expose additional CI details from UCMDB in Service Management. Simply go to Studio, add a new attribute to the data model, and link the new attribute with an attribute from UCMDB.

Furthermore, it is now possible to trigger workflow actions based on CI changes happening in UCMDB. Any federated UCMDB attributes can be used in the Service Management workflow engine to cover your business requirements. In the example below, an email is sent when Universal Discovery changes the serial number of a CI.

Multi-tenant and data domain rules 

With Native SACM, the tenant model and data domain rules in Service Management are fully transparent to UCMDB. In one farm, every Service Management tenant can have its own UCMDB customer to be uniquely connected with in the same UCMDB instance. You no longer need to set up another UCMDB instance for each Service Management tenant. This also applies to the logical data separation called Data Domain Segmentation in Service Management. This feature works transparently with UCMDB to ensure data security across the whole suite. 

Possible scenarios: 

Explanation of the multi-customer and multi-tenant concept of UCMDB can be found here:

UCMDB Multi-Tenancy Architecture vs. Multi-Customer Architecture (Classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB) or Multi-Tenancy Architecture vs. Multi-Customer Architecture (Containerized OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB). 

Behind the scenes

Adopt Native SACM for a fresh installation

Native SACM can be enabled in the following modes:

  • Classic mode: Service Management connecting with Classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB
  • Multi-deployment mode: Both Service Management and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB are containerized and deployed on OMT
  • Hybrid mode: Service Management is installed in a cloud environment and connects with a classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB running on-premises

Classic mode

The Native SACM solution requires an OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB system to work with Service Management. The following diagram shows the architecture of integrating Native SACM with Classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB.

Using shared IdM in classic mode

Deploying ClassicOpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB with the shared IdM brings the following benefits:

  • You only need to configure User/Group/Role settings like LDAP and SAML configurations once, for both Service Management and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB. You don't need to apply the configurations on both sides.
  • Single Sign-On between Service Management and UCMDB enables a seamless user experience when navigating through the UI elements.

In this mode, you need to enable OpenText™ Universal Discovery and the CMDB multi-customer mode to align with the Service Management multi-tenancy mode. In a real-world environment, configuring shared Identity Management (IdM) and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB for multi-customer mode can be complex. For more details, refer to the section on associating Service Management tenants with UCMDB customers for Single Sign-On.

Not using shared IdM in classic mode

If you don’t need Single Sign-On between Service Management and UCMDB in the Native SACM context, Service Management uses IdM to achieve user authentication, while Classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB has its user management controlled by UCMDB. This means the management of users, groups, roles, and permissions happens in Service Management and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB individually. For this option, no additional configurations are required during the Classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB installation, and multi-customer mode is optional in this scenario. 

Containerized multi-deployment mode

Using shared IdM in containerized multi-deployment mode
In containerized multi-deployment mode, using separate IdMs for Service Management and OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB is not supported.

Hybrid mode 

The hybrid mode follows the principles of a classic OpenText™ Universal Discovery and CMDB deployment. The only difference is that UCMDB is running on-premises, and the Service Management suite is in the cloud. See Native SACM hybrid mode. 

Upgrade Service Management and/or UCMDB in a Native-SACM-enabled deployment

In general, to use Native SACM, the difference in versions of Service Management and UCMDB needs to be the current version plus/minus 1. For example, Native SACM can work between Service Management 2021.05 and UCMDB 2021.05/2021.02. The only exception is Service Management 2020.11. You have to run it with UCMDB 2020.11 to get Native SACM working. For details, see Prepare for the Native SACM deployment.
